Response.SayText: What do I care of Edison's misfortune? I'm working!*stomp* Don't bother me again.
Nikola Tesla has been |locked in his cabin| since the theft. That seems suspicious to me.
I saw Mark Twain hiding something in a |secret compartment| in his cabin! Maybe it was Edison's device!
That device was going to make me the star of the fair.*cry* You've got to find it!
Whoever stole it couldn't have gotten off the train, which means the device is still onboard. Find the device, and you'll find the thief!
I've been in the engine room this whole time. and I've got the coal marks to prove it!
Astonishing that something could vanish into thin air like that. What a trick!
Quelle disappointment!*grief* I was looking forward to seeing Monsieur Edison's device in action!
I'm sorry to hear about Mr. Edison's troubles, but I've got problems of my own.
This is going to reflect very poorly on the railroad company!
Suspicious folks all around, but none moreso than whoever is riding in the last car. That fella's behind more security than my memoirs!
The missing motion capture device... I should ask everybody on the train about it and see what they know.
Nikola Tesla has been locked in his cabin since the theft. That seems suspicious to me.
I didn't notice anything unusual, but I'll keep trying to remember anything suspicious.
It's like Tesla to retreat from the world. What an odd duck.
Monsieur Tesla didn't even glance at me when I passed him earlier. What an unfriendly person.
Don't know anything about him. I just shovel coal.
Disappearing isn't such a difficult trick.
I did hear a cabin door open and close when we went through the tunnel. It could have been Tesla's.
I can't get Tesla to talk to me either. But I have so much to talk to him about!
Don't bother Mr. Tesla. Our cabin doors have locks for a reason.
Sometimes a man just wants some peace and quiet. Nothing wrong with that.
Susan B. Anthony said that Tesla is hiding in his room. I should find a way in there.
What's this about you and a secret compartment here in this cabin?
That's nonsense!*tremble* Of course I don't have a secret compartment.
Then you won't mind if I have a look around.
Of... of course not!*tremble* I have nothing to hide!
I saw Mark Twain hiding something in a secret compartment in his cabin! Maybe it was Edison's device!
Yes, I think the device could fit in a space that size. You should investigate!
After the comments he's made about people from other countries, I wouldn't put anything past Twain.
He wrote Tom Sawyer, didn't he?*proud* I love that song.
Anything can be hidden from the casual observer.
Odd, I don't think my cabin has a hidden compartment.
Why are you asking me about Twain's cabin?
Hmph, I would know if our train cars contained hidden compartments. At least, I think I would...
Nothing is more frustrating than when someone is withholding what's rightfully yours, wouldn't you say?
The reporter said Mark Twain is hiding something in a secret compartment. I should investigate.
Why are you asking me about Twain's cabin?
Interesting... it looks like the trail heads away from my cabin and toward the coal car.
I love prune juice, but I haven't had any yet on this trip.
The only place to get prune juice on board is on the dining car.
Prune juice? Blech!
Such a waste of delicious prune juice!
Prune juice is the last thing I need with this motion sickness.
Is the juice fermented? Non? Then I shall pass.
I can't help you. Sorry.
I only drink water. It's the healthiest drink.
I can't tell you what our passengers ordered! That is confidential information!
There were fresh prune juice stains on the floor outside Edison's cabin. That could mean that the thief was drinking it. I need to find out who ordered prune juice.
Okay, okay!*grief* I did leave to |get a snack|, and that's when the train stopped. But I didn't go near the luggage! You can ask the Porter!
Coal isn't easy to wash off. Whoever was in the luggage area probably still has coal marks on them.
Why don't you ask the coal man about it?
Such filth... I shudder to imagine getting that foulness on myself!
That's coal, no doubt about it. Pretty obvious who that points to.
Urk, those coal fumes... Get it away from me!
To think, a rock that is thousands of years old can power a train!
I explored the idea of powering my wheel with coal, but the smoke would be too unpleasant for the passengers.
Coal smudges!?*stomp* What was that incompetent coal man doing in the luggage car?
Coal dust is black as night. That could come in handy someday.
That's odd... what was the coal man doing around the passengers' luggage?
Why don't you ask the coal man about it?

Clue.name: Snack
Clue.displayName: coal man left for a snack

Response.SayText: I just left for a snack. I didn't go near the luggage!*grief* You can ask the Porter.
That's true, he was here getting something to eat when the train stopped. So he couldn't have stopped the train.
I didn't go near the luggage!*grief* You can ask the porter!
The porter doesn't take orders from the coal man. The coal man would have had to have left the coal car.
I suppose it's possible that someone else could have snuck into the coal car if the coal man left.
Americans*laugh* - always eating!
If it had been the coal man I'd heard, we probably would have seen coal footprints on the floor instead of prune juice stains.
No one around here values the sweet sting of sweat in their eyes from a hard day's work.
I was here the whole time, but I don't remember seeing the coal man. Perhaps he took a different route to the dining car?
Sometimes I think I should have taken a common job like the coal man did.
The porter should know if the coal man left the coal car.
The coal man says he was getting a snack. I need to find someone who can support his alibi.
The porter should know if the coal man was getting a snack.
How did you see what was written on my orders sheet?*stomp* It must be miles away by now!
The porter never takes my order, because I'm not a passenger.
Tesla hasn't left his cabin since we left Washington D.C. The prune juice must be catching up to him by now.
It is strange that Tesla won't leave his room, even ordering room service instead of going to the dining car.
Tesla has awful taste - not that there are any good options on the menu.
How can somebody make it this long without going to the bathroom?
Tesla got his prune juice already? Then why am I still waiting for my bicarbonate of soda?
If Tesla won't talk to you himself, perhaps you could see if there's any more evidence in his luggage.
I guess you'd expect someone as brilliant as Tesla to have some quirks.
If Tesla made that juice disappear in a flash, it'll probably reappear just as quickly.
I need to ask Tesla a few questions, but he won't talk to me. Maybe there's a clue in his luggage?
When we went around that curve, Tesla was all the way on the other side of the train!
I knew it. But you realize what this means?
The thief is still on the loose!
Make haste and talk to Tesla. Perhaps he knows something that can help us.
I have proof that Mr. Tesla is innocent!
Buzz off. This one's open and shut.
I've always enjoyed the view of the train going around that curve. Who knew it could be used to solve a crime?
Good thing we had to slow down to go around that curve, or the image might have been blurry.
What sort of wizardry is this? That looks just like Nikola Tesla!
In the future, this kind of technology will probably be a great help to police and reporters.
Wow,*proud* where can I get a device like that?
Nothing can surpass the written word for truth and clarity.
Incredible!*proud* Mr. Edison's device could see so far out the window!
Hmph,*cry* I guess the motion capture device will be the main attraction at the fair if I can't fix the wheel.
I can see why someone would steal that. You could make a lot of money with such a device.
When we went around that curve, Tesla was all the way on the other side of the train! The thief is still on the loose!
I don't know how it was opened.*grief* The key is still around my neck!
That lock looks like it was picked by an expert.*proud* No, |I don't know anyone| like that. Excuse me.
I've never invented a gizmo to break through a lock. That would be unethical.
Nobody could have gotten in through Tesla's cabin. Our doors are impregnable!
I'd have to save up for a fancy case like that, but I'd get coal dust all over it.
Tesla should have used a case with a combination lock. Keys can be stolen or copied.
A high-end model. Functional and fashionable.
It wouldn't have been easy to get into that case without a good set of tools.
What a ride. I didn't expect the great train robbery!
I should keep my own effects close at hand. There are thieves about!
How was the case opened? More importantly, what was in the case?
Tesla has the only key. How did the thief open the briefcase?
The case doesn't look damaged. You should find someone who could have picked the lock.
I don't know what you're talking about!
Mr. Weisz is very strange. He seems to appear and disappear at will.
Weisz? What kind of a name is Weisz?*laugh* I don't trust him.
Of everyone on board, only Mr. Weisz seems to have no reason to be here.
I have not spoken with Monsieur Weisz. I haven't even seen him.
He did ask me about the inner workings of my wheel. He seemed a little too interested.
I saw him lurking around near my cabin earlier. I got distracted, and when I turned back he had vanished.
I think I saw him heading toward the coal car earlier.
Nope, haven't seen him up here.
Mr. Weisz is a paying customer. I know nothing more.
Something has been bothering me about this Weisz character. Doesn't he look familiar? Look at this article.
Weisz acted strangely when he mentioned that the lock was picked by an expert.
I don't know anything about Erik Weisz.
You've found out my true identity, but can you catch me?
All this time, we were traveling with a famous magician?
Houdini's trickery and flimflammery don't impress me.
Houdini? The Harry Houdini? You should take a closer look in his cabin.
I understand how Monsieur Houdini would break into Tesla's briefcase, but I do not understand why.
They do look a lot alike.
It must have been Houdini who broke into my briefcase.*grief* Find him!
Like most Americans, Houdini is a thief. Did you know he stole his name from the French magician Robert Houdin?
I don't recall seeing Weisz onboard. I'm sure I would have recognized him. Everyone knows Houdini!
I did think it was strange that this Weisz fellow was onboard with so many celebrities.
Houdini can definitely pick a lock. Maybe his lockpicks are still in his room.
Erik Weisz looks a lot like Harry Houdini. Could they be the same person?
They do look a lot alike.
All right, Tesla, come clean. What were you hiding?
Let me out of here and I'll talk.[pick his lock]
I was carrying a small transformer capable of generating an enormous amount of wattage. Only this device would provide enough electricity to power the Ferris Wheel.
Why would somebody steal that?
Egotistic fools – nobody wants to be upstaged by the Wheel!
I can't imagine what Tesla had in that case. You should ask him.
Don't ask me about Tesla's tomfoolery. Ask Tesla.
Professional curiosity does lead me to wonder what Tesla had in that case.
If you know what was stolen from Tesla, you may be able to determine who had the motive.
Whatever Tesla had might have been able to help me.*grief* Please, you've got to find it!
I'm sure Tesla was carrying another one of his useless gadgets.
If I wanted this much excitement in the workplace, I'd have taken that whaling job on the Pequod!
I'd tell you to stop bothering my passengers, but I guess we're well past that point.
If you can find out what was in that case, you'll have the scoop of a lifetime.
Weisz... er, Houdini... said to find what Tesla was hiding, and I would find the thief.
Hmph. Inferior workmanship.
It's the very thing that could save my wheel!*grief* You've got to find it!
That drawing means nothing to me, but if you asked me, I'd say Gustave Eiffel is the most likely suspect. He has the most to lose if the Ferris Wheel is a success.
You still don't know who the thief is, and you've talked to everyone on board – except that |mysterious fellow| in the last car. Talk to him and you may find the truth.
Electrical? How gauche.*laugh* Monsieur Eiffel's tower never needed such artificial assistance.
Buddy, nobody in the big city is going to read a story about this little gizmo.*laugh* But the Ferris Wheel - now that's a scoop!
If it ain't coal-fired, I ain't interested.
That looks quite small. It could be hidden almost anywhere on this train!
Electrical engineering is beyond me. I build solid structures.
My transformer - my greatest invention!
This looks like it belongs in the Ferris Wheel.
I don't know anything about that.

Clue.name: Silhouette
Clue.displayName: mysterious fellow in the last car

Response.SayText: It would take a genius to thwart the security and reach the last car. Are you a genius?
Please, get to the last car and talk to the mysterious person! You're my only hope!
The Pinkerton guard is a tough cookie, but I saw him napping outside the last car. Maybe you can sneak by.
You still don’t know who the thief is, and you’ve talked to everyone on board – except that mysterious fellow in the last car. Talk to him and you may find the truth.
Good luck trying to get past all of the traps at the rear of the car.
I have a theory about who's on the last car. I think it's someone very important. You should go check it out.
Don't ask me who's back there. I've learned my lesson about leaving the coal car.
Let the spirit of curiosity take you wherever it may lead!
That fellow has the right idea. Leaving your cabin is never a good idea.
Security is tight in the last car. But I wouldn't put anything past you.
There's a mysterious fellow in the last car, but it's heavily guarded.
I don't know who's in the last car, and I don't think they want us to know, either.
All those French curios must point to Gustave Eiffel!
Mr. Eiffel is trying to sabotage me?*grief* No, I don't believe it!
You never could trust a Frenchman.
What a long way to travel just to commit a crime.
Another promising mind done in by his own ego.
The evidence is overwhelming. Monsieur Eiffel is in the cabin car.
I'd still like to see his tower one day.
This never would have happened if the fair had been held in New York*stomp* instead of Chicago.
It's true: I'm French. But you've overlooked one very important detail. This is a lady's handkerchief!
It must be the Le Monde reporter. She doesn't want the Chicago fair to upstage Paris!
Various French books and other items from France... and a handkerchief smudged with coal dust!
Don't ask me. It's not my trunk.
I need to talk to Tesla in the coal car, but the Pinkerton agent is blocking the entrance.
If you can't go through him, you could always try going over or around the guard.
The guard won't stop you from heading back that way, I'm sure.
A brave person could probably move about the train by walking on top of it. Or a foolish person!
Don't expect the Pinkerton man to listen to reason. He wouldn't even take a pamphlet!
I do not like that guard one bit.
Even I don't have the authority to move the guard from his post.
You don't need my help. You already found your way in here!
You'll never outmuscle that guard. You'll have to outfox him.
When all else fails, look to the sky!
Some of these train cars have hatches on the roof.
I'd stay away from the Pinkerton man if I were you.
